Title: âš ï¸ DEPLOYMENT BLOCKER: customer experiencing high latency peaks with watsonx BYOM
Labels: Production Deployment Blocker, Japan, watsonx.ai, watsonx products
Comments: keely: @vijesh-bhaktha will follow up on this vijesh-bhaktha: This is a known issue as we have capacity issues with BYOM due to unavailability of GPUs. So customers trying to deploy BYOM may face error due to unavailability of GPUs under the hood. We are working on ways to address this issue. but the underlying issue is still GPU availability which the team has very little influence over. We have leadership attention on this as well. Wolf-Bocanett: @vijesh-bhaktha thanks for chiming in but as the title says and the attached GH issue describe, this is not an issue of GPU unavailability but rather an issue with the platform latency after already having a deployment with a GPU. We found a possible solution and just communicated it to the client earlier today, but as for the GPU availability, the client has tried today to deploy another deployment in a different DC to test out a parameter update that should solve their latency problem but seems like they ran into the GPU issue as seen in the screenshot: ![image (18)](https://github.ibm.com/customer-success-management/data-watsonx/assets/182647/08278629-6582-4104-afbc-20845f32fccb) ![image (19)](https://github.ibm.com/customer-success-management/data-watsonx/assets/182647/d74d87c8-c3b2-49ae-b2c3-edd415b4fb2b) So, if customers are trying to use BYOM and can't due to GPUs availability, who would be the right people to influence this and to work with on resolving this? TALS: Try to reach out to David Tam - watsonx.ai DevOp manager Wolf-Bocanett: Thanks @TALS , figured that already and got David Tam across it and I am getting his team's help already. We plan to redeploy with the team's assistant tomorrow. keely: @Wolf-Bocanett How did the redeploy go? Wolf-Bocanett: Redeployment involved a live call with said personnel and was completed successfully. Now our last blocker is model quality on BYOM (seems like some LLM parameters are not working which is affecting quality) and getting the team to respond to this is pretty slow still (see related github issue). keely: @Wolf-Bocanett Looks like an update was provided a few days ago. Is the response sufficient that we can close this issue? keely: @Wolf-Bocanett please see my question above Wolf-Bocanett: Client has yet re-deploy and to test the resolution due to other priorities. I'm going to go ahead and close this for the time being and in parallel we are requesting help with internal IBM on validating this resolution internally to provide the client with further confidence that this is resolved.

Labels: help wanted, watsonx.ai, ISA, watsonx.gov, watsonx products
Comments: keely: @More-Manish Yes, you can install on Azure Cloud or hybrid (Azure + on-prem). I suggest reaching out to Amit Banik, he is a tech sales leader who co-authored a couple articles about wx.gov and wx.ai on Azure: https://developer.ibm.com/articles/awb-watsonx-governance-responsible-transparent-explainable-ai/ https://developer.ibm.com/articles/awb-introducing-watsonx-ai-on-microsoft-azure/ keely: Call on Feb 21st with people Amit recommended we reach out to keely: @keely to add notes from Feb 21 mtg keely: Email from Build Engineering team not recommending this approach: Hi Sheetal, From the below thread it appears that you are looking to deploy watsonx.ai onto an on-premises OpenShift deployment and the GPU nodes on-premises are not yet available. As such, you are looking to deploy the base watsonx.ai onto the on-premises cluster and use one or more remote GPU nodes on Azure for the prompt tuning and inference model(s). Please advise if this is incorrect. It is technically possible to configure remote worker nodes, such as the GPU nodes, providing that the network latency can be kept within a tolerated amount. However, it is not recommended, particularly when the workload is split between worker nodes, as is the case with watsonx.ai. Normally this configuration of OpenShift would only be considered in cases where the remote workload is isolated to those nodes and the control plane is remote. For example, IoT applications with central control plane and multiple remote worker nodes each doing a specific job with little to no communication between sets of worker nodes. In the case of watsonx.ai, the workload would be split between two different sets of worker nodes, on-premises and remote on Azure. Some of the reasons to not use remote GPU nodes include: Significant performance degradation. Complexity to configure. Storage on-premises with remote processing Not a watsonx.ai supported configuration. WAN connectivity required between on-premises and Azure. Rich Ehrhardt Principal Cloud Engineer Ecosystem Engineering Build Engineering IBM Worldwide Ecosystem Phone: [+61 419 206 724](tel:+61419206724) Email: [rich_ehrhardt@au1.ibm.com](mailto:rich_ehrhardt@au1.ibm.com) keely: @More-Manish What did the team decide to do? keely: @More-Manish What was decided with this customer implementation? More-Manish: @keely , let me check with the CSM and update More-Manish: @keely , checked with the CSM Sheetal Deshmukh. The customer has decided to not go with Hybrid approach and are procuring GPU on-premise. keely: Wonderful! Is it okay if we close this issue @More-Manish ? keely: @More-Manish is it okay to close this issue now? keely: I am closing this issue since the customer has decided to procure on-prem GPUs.

Title: Support for AMD EPYC 9J14 and AMD EPYC 7J13 with CP4D and watsonx
Labels: help wanted, EMEA, CP4D, watsonx products
Comments: Samet-Kilictas: Customer is planing to utilize these processors to have [confidential computing capabilities provided on CPU level](https://docs.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Compute/References/confidential_compute.htm), considering Redhat certifies Oracle HW from Openshift perspective, customer is checking with IBM to see if these CPUs are ok from IBM Software perspective. As side note, we know that IBM did not certified the [Oracle DRCC environment](https://github.ibm.com/customer-success-management/data-watsonx/issues/331) however as these are baremetal servers, it does not impact the IBM Software other than the original question around CPU. FRANKO: @Sachin-Prasad1 and @ck-rao who can assist Samet with this urgent case? FRANKO: Added tags keely: @Samet-Kilictas please ping @Mekki-MacAulay for clarification, and update the issue as needed. keely: @Samet-Kilictas did you get any clarification on this from Mekki? Mekki-MacAulay: Yes, we met and discussed. I believe @Samet-Kilictas has everything he needs now. Should be good to close. Samet-Kilictas: @keely Yes, we had discussion with @Mekki-MacAulay it was really good. We also covered https://github.ibm.com/customer-success-management/data-watsonx/issues/331 case as well. To avoid confusion, this ticket is about inquiry on CPUs supported. While we know that in general there is no CPU restrictions as long as it is in the supported architecture, however I can see for watsonx Assistant, there is specific ask as below:  Reference: https://www.ibm.com/docs/en/software-hub/5.1.x?topic=requirements-x86-64-hardware https://openbenchmarking.org/s/2+x+AMD+EPYC+9J14+96-Core#:~:text=The%202%20x%20AMD%20EPYC,a%20%22Zen%204%22%20processor. So my question is around if there are any other needs or we can say officially "OK" to customer when they are installing the CP4D on AMD cpu listed above. Mekki-MacAulay: SSE 4.2 and AVX2 have been supported by all Intel and AMD CPUs since 2011, so the EPYC line are fine. And the 9J14 and 7J13 are both typically >2.4 GHz per core tuned (usually configured that way but can actually be 2.0 GHz to 3.7 GHz so depends how Oracle has configured them in the data center; it should be visible in the Oracle vCPU configuration panel), so good there as well. Sources: - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Advanced_Vector_Extensions - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SSE4 - https://www.amd.com/en/products/processors/server/epyc/7003-series/amd-epyc-7713.html (7J13 is the Oracle OEM exclusive version of the 7713) - https://www.amd.com/en/products/processors/server/epyc/4th-generation-9004-and-8004-series/amd-epyc-9654.html (9J14 is the Oracle OEM exclusive version of the 9654) Samet-Kilictas: Ok I shared the outcome to customer as these CPUs are supported as per their architecture and there is no known problem with them. keely: @Samet-Kilictas Has this issue been resolved? Samet-Kilictas: I got the answer from product team members as there is no CPU specification for specific CPU models. Therefore, the case can be closed.

Title: [watsonx.ai SW + SaaS] Text Extraction API - German Handwriting (Health Insurance)
Comments: ck-rao: @vijesh-bhaktha will get back on the details and some features release dates. nisarg-patel: Have you explored using any of the vision models on watsonx.ai like Llama 3.2 or pixtral-12b? WATMANN: @nisarg-patel - thanks, took a look at https://huggingface.co/ibm-granite/granite-vision-3.1-2b-preview , but seems to be English only. We will take a look at Llama/Pixtral. Though the question is more on the roadmap of the watsonx.ai document extraction service being able to process also (German) handwritten documents plus annotated PDFs (checkmarks, additional handwritten notes, etc. ). Is it planned to extend watsonx.ai Text Extraction into that domain? Any roadmap where this document extraction service is heading? Thanks! keely: @WATMANN Did the Llama or Pixtral models work? peter-bradford-ibm: Using the Bring Your Own Model (BYOM) offering, another option is to use an open source vision models which understands German... 1. Model: **Tesseract** - Handwriting support: Weak - German support: Yes - Strengths: Fast, lightweight - Limitations: Bad for cursive handwriting - Reference documentation: GitHub: https://github.com/tesseract-ocr/tesseract, Pre-trained German Models: https://github.com/tesseract-ocr/langdata_lstm, Installation Guide: https://tesseract-ocr.github.io/tessdoc/Installation.html 2. Model: **TrOCR (Microsoft's Transformer-based OCR)** - Handwriting support: Yes - German support: Yes - Strengths: Best for modern handwriting, fine-tunable - Limitations: Needs fine-tuning for historical scripts - Reference documentation: Hugging Face Model: https://huggingface.co/microsoft/trocr-base-handwritten, Hugging Face Repository: https://huggingface.co/models?search=trocr, GitHub: https://github.com/microsoft/unilm/tree/master/trocr 3. Model: **Donut (OCR-Free Document Transformer by Clova AI)** - Handwriting support: Yes - German support: Yes, but better with fine-tuning - Strengths: No need for bounding boxes, works with various document types - Limitations: Not specifically trained on handwriting - Reference documentation: Hugging Face Model: https://huggingface.co/naver-clova-ix/donut-base, GitHub: https://github.com/clovaai/donut, Paper: https://arxiv.org/abs/2111.15664 4. Model: **Kraken (OCR for Historical and Handwritten German Scripts)** - Handwriting support: Yes - German support: Yes (supports Fraktur, Kurrent, SÃ¼tterlin) - Strengths: Great for historical German handwriting, customizable - Limitations: Needs custom training - Reference documentation: GitHub: https://github.com/mittagessen/kraken, Documentation: https://kraken.re/ 5. Model: **Calamari OCR (Deep Learning OCR for Fraktur/Kurrent)** - Handwriting support: Yes - German support: Yes - Strengths: Strong for Fraktur/Kurrent, customizable - Limitations: Requires training for non-standard handwriting - Reference documentation: GitHub: https://github.com/Calamari-OCR/calamari, Hugging Face Model: https://huggingface.co/Calamari-OCR, Paper: https://arxiv.org/abs/1807.02004 WATMANN: Thanks @peter-bradford-ibm and @keely - evaluating options with the team. keely: @WATMANN Any update on this one? keely: @WATMANN Any update on this one? WATMANN: The Team worked on leveraging Docling directly (testing Tesseract and EasyOCR engine). The plan is to only very selectively use foundation models, we need though a scalable base OCR engine for the bulk of the documents. Besides the handwriting we struggle with throughput performance. Some testing of Docling+EasyOCR on NVIDIA L4 GPU is currently ongoing. In parallel we are looking also into the watsonx. ai Text Extraction API, but it lacks in the return structure position information / bounding boxes currently used in the python backend pipeline. It seems only a subset of https://pages.github.ibm.com/ai-foundation/watson_doc_understanding/current/getting-started/python/ is exposed through watsonx.ai Text Extraction. We have follow up calls with Peter Staar and Laura Chiticariu to discuss on the proper OCR approach going forward. keely: @WATMANN how did the discussion go with Peter and Laura? keely: @WATMANN how did the discussion go with Peter and Laura? WATMANN: We had good discussions with both Peter and Laura. After some testing the team prefers to go down the Docling route - a combination of docling + docling serve on a L4 IBM Cloud VPC VSI to get started. The current implementation is leveraging docling in a single Code Engine application which is clearly not scaling well. Fixing this has current priority. vLLM pipelines might be sth. to look at, but the basics need to be up and running first currently.  keely: With this new solution can we close this issue? keely: @WATMANN A new version of the text extraction API in IBM Cloud is available now (WDU 2.3), see this [Slack post](https://ibm-analytics.slack.com/archives/C019RCY6Z9D/p1748955610340209). Hoping this will help address your issues? WATMANN: @keely - thanks for the info about the new WDU service. Project will continue its Phase 2 in two weeks. Lets close that issue for now. Thanks for chasing!

Comments: Samet-Kilictas: Here is further information: - Oracle Confidential Computing is available in DRCC with AMD E4 and E5 for both VMs and Bare Metal shapes. [[documentation](https://docs.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Compute/References/confidential_compute.htm#confidential_compute__coco_support) and [Blog](https://blogs.oracle.com/cloud-infrastructure/post/protect-data-in-use-with-confidential-computing)] - Azure ARO with Confidential Computing support [blog](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/openshift/confidential-containers-overview) keely: @Sachin-Prasad1 Please provide a status on this. Samet-Kilictas: **Note here:** Some CPUs as mentioned in this support case: https://github.ibm.com/customer-success-management/data-watsonx/issues/335 enabled confidential computing without any inference with application deployed on top it. Which is the simplest way to enable it. However we must define our approaches for confidential computing when using other methods. (e.g. CoCo from Redhat)

Title: Looking for GPU specific information for sizing - miss the GPU data in below documentation
Labels: documentation, help wanted, EMEA, watsonx.ai, GPU issue
Comments: FRANKO: @crescenzo-migliaccio need help with above @robert-stanich can you assist ? @TALS fyi keely: @keely Find doc Slack channel and GH repo keely: [Added a request](https://ibm-analytics.slack.com/archives/C07QRUH3Z50/p1738953208984939) to the #watsonx-doc-feedback Slack channel. michelle-miller: Scroll to the right in the table and you will see the column you're looking for (shard = GPU)  apsteven: Also we watsonxai supports GPUs with 48, 80 and 96 GB VRAM. Plus likely other variations in the future. So we should specify total VRAM required. Also include the large context windows, as a 128K token context window can consume another 40 GB of VRAM. I.e. a Llama-70b requires only 4 x H100 80GB but would need 6 x L40 48GB. ABAKY: @michelle-miller is it written somewhere that **shard** means **GPU**? A glossary page would be useful. But I don't see a glossary page in the [IBM Software Hub documentation](https://www.ibm.com/docs/en/software-hub/5.1.x). crescenzo-migliaccio: For consistency reason and avoid misunderstanding I would suggest to add a simple label like "GPUs" under *System requirements* column, since there we have already the number of CPU and RAM dimension. Furthermore I would remove the label "Number of shards" in the "supported gpu" column The final result will be like below (I have just used inspect element to change the HTML): ![Image](https://github.ibm.com/customer-success-management/data-watsonx/assets/2262/90b2a240-683f-44a7-98a0-c1b14d69751f) michelle-miller: Thank you for the suggestion! We met with some folks from development yesterday to discuss this table and have some ideas for how to make it clearer, similar to what you are suggesting, in fact. I can add the revised table here to get some feedback after it's updated if you're willing to give it a look. crescenzo-migliaccio: @michelle-miller sure, thank you ! apsteven: To be fully accurate, we should list the actually GPU memory requirement (including context window VRAM) as it's not the "number of GPUs" but total VRAM requirements. So we should actually provide a calculator rather than a table. michelle-miller: Thanks for all this feedback. Things got a bit frantic as the end of the release schedule there. There are updates to the docs that reflect your requests, but we might not have incorporated all of the suggestions. Hopefully, this table is better. And we do plan to keep make improvements in the next release. https://www.ibm.com/docs/en/software-hub/5.1.x?topic=install-foundation-models keely: @FRANKO Please see the updates to the docs, and let us know if it is sufficient to close this issue? keely: Frank says "all good" :)

TALS: You can read here - https://www.ibm.com/docs/en/watsonx/saas?topic=models-foundation-model-lifecycle 3-1-70b-instruct has started its deprecation period and will be available until end of May 3-70b-instruct got **special relief** until the end of March. ana-perez-hoyos: then the deprecation period for llama3.1 has been extended, which according to ibm policy should have been 30 days after the notice, right? TALS: Right. 30 days is IBM's legal/official commitment, but according to availability IBM tries to give more than that as listed in the lifecycle link ana-perez-hoyos: Hi, They are planning to move to mixtral large because of llama 3.1 70b deprecation. Is there any information about the deprecation of mixtral that is not public yet? or any info that can give them more safety? TALS: To get the maximum time/value, I advise taking the latest model which has just been introduced last week - Mistral-Small-24B-Instruct-2501 It has great performance and low cost which makes it great value for money. If it doesn't fit the next option is Mistral large No deprecation dates as been published @robert-stanich - any additional insight? robert-stanich: the current state of the art model is llama3.3-70B. that is what they should move to. it's actually the same base model as 3.1-70B, it's just better at math, non-english languages, and instruction following. but i'll warn that we're expecting llama4 and yet another update to mistral-large sooner that you'd expect. customers are going to need to get more nimble in terms of how they upgrade to newer ai models. the pace of change is only increasing. FRANKO: Thanks @robert-stanich why the proactive customer facing material @Mekki-MacAulay is working will be so important ana-perez-hoyos: The problem here is that currently llama 3.3 has a much higher latency. That is why they have not considered migrating to this model, is there any indication that this will change? if not, they prefer to switch to mistral-large as the latency is more similar to llama3.1. what is the estimated upgrade time for mistral-large? telling to customers that they have to be more agile in the migration of models when BYOM is not in Frankfurt does not seem like a good option to me. @robert-stanich keely: Targeted for mid Mar keely: @ana-perez-hoyos Deploy on Demand and BYOM is now available in Frankfurt! https://dataplatform.cloud.ibm.com/docs/content/wsj/getting-started/whats-new-wx.html?context=wx&audience=wdp @FRANKO fyi keely: Hi @ana-perez-hoyos Can we close this issue now? I have told the account team that the policy for non-IBM models is 30 days notice of removal (per https://github.ibm.com/customer-success-management/watsonx/issues/235) and they are shocked at such a short notice period for our customers for a production service. They have the following questions - - Any chance of an extension - How is this a reasonable notice period / help with convincing the client of the answer- they canâ€™t be the only ones asking? - Lessons for op model going forward if this is going to be a recurring issue TALS: The official period is 30, but PM gave a heads up message that was sent to all the GEOs on October 1st 2024. This is a period of 4 months. This should have gave the clients enough time to move to a newer model ![2025-01-22_12-59-13](https://github.ibm.com/customer-success-management/watsonx/assets/71412/efb3a7f6-82f1-43e8-afb0-01276b591ee3) Also you can find the model life cycle in this link - https://www.ibm.com/docs/en/watsonx/saas?topic=models-foundation-model-lifecycle TALS: Just to add that the email included a message written by PM to be sent to clients with explanation on the benefits of moving to newer models robert-stanich: This model will be running in Sydney until the end of March. They can just change their region over there if they want to go into "overtime." COOPERL: Hi Robert, thanks but NatWest operate under banking regulations that require them to only work with IT systems in EMEA, so unfortunately this won't work for them. Please can you extend the availability of this model in EMEA? ck-rao: @TALS is working with @robert-stanich on this extension decision. Mark and I had a call with the NatWest team this morning, they are currently on track to move to llama 3.3 March 18th. keely: Docs updated to say deprecation to Mar 31st. keely: @COOPERL Did NatWest move to llama 3.3 yesterday? Title: Granite 3.1 Korean Support and Training Data Comparison with 3.0
Comments: keely: Ajay Varshney will look into this Ajay-Varshney: Hi @wuhu, who can help address this question please? Ajay-Varshney: @Gwangsu-Kim The base model and pre-training data is the same for granite 3.1 and granite 3.0 for Korean language, but the post training data is different. - The multilingual 3.0 pre-training data had about 2.2% Korean words out of the 11 supported languages, so for phase2-pretraining you can assume around 2% (2B tokens) of the tokens out of the 100B multilingual tokens were Korean. - For 3.1 post-training, there was a bit more focus on Korean language, e.g. for the NLP datasets (one smaller portion of the data) that went into post-training, around 20% of samples came from Korean datasets. Granite 3.1 technical report is expected to come out by end of January so that will provide more details on the training datasets used. @keely FYI. Gwangsu-Kim: @Ajay-Varshney Thanks, When you refer to "post-training," are you talking about the addition of datasets through synthetic data generation? Ajay-Varshney: @Gwangsu-Kim post-training is not just limited to synthetic data. The granite 3.0 technical paper from IBM Research talks about post-training methods and datasets in detail - https://github.com/ibm-granite/granite-3.0-language-models/blob/main/paper.pdf.

Title: Limiting Target Fields for Natural Language Search in Watson Discovery
Comments: dilang: Have you tried filters in DQL (Discovery Query Language)? https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/discovery-data?topic=discovery-data-query-dql-overview keely: @Yusaku-Ono did you try the filters in DQL linked to above? Yusaku-Ono: @dilang @keely Yes, we are using DQL for searches that are not based on natural language queries. However, the current request is specifically about performing natural language searches (NLQ) on specific fields. For example, if a document contains fields like "Title," "Abstract," and "Body," the current natural language search targets all fields. However, there are cases where we only want to perform a natural language search on a specific field, such as "Abstract." It would be extremely helpful if DQL syntax could allow combining NLQ for such cases. Does the suggested use of DQL filters align with the intent of our request? If not, is there an existing feature or planned enhancement that addresses this requirement? dilang: @Yusaku-Ono I am not aware of this feature on the roadmap. Can you create an AHA idea? Also add business impact to the RFE. Yusaku-Ono: @dilang Thank you for the clarification. I understand. I will create an AHA idea for this. Thanks!

Title: [SaaS, IBM Cloud, Frankfurt] watsonx (.ai/.governance/.data/Assistants) Services - BSI C5 Certification
Labels: EMEA, watsonx.ai, watsonx.data, watsonx.gov, SaaS, Product: Security, watsonx products, Product Scout
Comments: ck-rao: @Mayank-Arora Would you look into this one, please? cir: @Mayank-Arora Reviewing. WATMANN: @ck-rao @Mayank-Arora @robert-stanich As we had our formal project kickoff yesterday with KKH --> Attached additional input from Thomas Eberle - ATL for the German pulic health insurances. Any input and guidance very welcome. This project has its current focus on **watsonx.ai** on IBM Cloud. IBM Sales Cloud entry for this win at KKH --> https://ibmsc.lightning.force.com/lightning/r/Opportunity/006Ka00000NXEJNIA5/view --- Input Thomas --- I am the Account Technical Leader for all German public health insurances, and we had a win Q4 last year including watsonx.ai and IBM Cloud resources. Our client is KKH, a public health insurance company in Germany. They are looking for a solution to improve a specific process with the power of generative AI and the ability to run it in the cloud, whereever possible. The German public health insurance market is a highly regulated market with very strict standards and compliances. For this specific use case social data (personal data processed by the health sector in Germany, including health insurances) is processed in this project. To process social data in the cloud, public health insurances in Germany have to make sure that the [C5 criteria catalogue](https://www.bsi.bund.de/EN/Themen/Unternehmen-und-Organisationen/Informationen-und-Empfehlungen/Empfehlungen-nach-Angriffszielen/Cloud-Computing/Kriterienkatalog-C5/kriterienkatalog-c5_node.html) is completely fulfilled. Thatâ€™s why we currently canâ€™t use any of the watsonx SaaS products, as it currently doesnâ€™t fulfil the C5 criteria catalogue. My team came up with the solution to install the on-prem version of watsonx.ai on a ROKS cluster in the IBM cloud. Itâ€™s also required, that the deployment runs in Germany: Thatâ€™s why we want to have the deployment running in Frankfurt. The client is interested in running this cloud account as an AI platform: He wants to initially start with the use case we are currently working on: Further use cases are already in the pipeline of the customer to be added to their AI platform. [@Gerd Watmann](mailto:WATMANN@de.ibm.com) told me that the flavour selection of the worker nodes for ROKS clusters in Frankfurt is limited, especially if we require GPUs for our project. We either have very small flavors (1/2xL40S) or very large ones (8xH100): There is nothing really in between, which - in our opinion - would be highly beneficial for our project. We also must stay economical, as we only have a limited Cloud budget for the clientâ€¦ We canâ€™t e.g. afford to run an 8-GPU worker node, especially if we only require less GPUs. On the other side, 2 GPUs might not be enough: Thatâ€™s why a flavour somewhere in the middle would be our optimal solution for starting the use case. We expect that â€“ in the worst case â€“ we require a worker node flavour with 4 GPUs. Besides: The optimal solution would be to run watsonx.ai as SaaS serviceâ€¦. Blocker is, as already stated, the C5 criteria catalogue I also heard of the ability to use a dedicated service for GPU resources (On Demand Hosting) on the roadmap. However, as far Gerd told me, we would have the same regulatory blocker with the C5 criteria catalogue. With all that background information, I have the following questions: â€¢ Do you know when can we expect to get such flexible flavours in the IBM Cloud? If not, do you know any contacts who can answer this question? â€¢ When can we expect to have C5 certified watsonx services in the IBM Cloud? Is it possible to escalate this concern? This project is a huge opportunity for us in the health insurance market in Germany. In order to be successful â€“ especially with watsonx â€“ we require higher flexibility and the fulfillment in the Frankfurt region of IBM Cloud. Your response therefore means a lot to me and my team. WATMANN: Any additional insights about that topic? Thanks! WATMANN: @FRANKO - this is e.g. an important one for the German market. In particular in Public / Health / etc. . FRANKO: @ck-rao @keely Who is assigned to work this ?I see no one assigned? It is moved to Assigned and Working but not sure I'm clear on owner? @robert-stanich @martin-rysanek I can see you where tagged by Campbell. keely: @WATMANN Please open an AHA Idea for this and we will track as part of Product Scout. And open a separate issue for the GPU issue. Mekki asking Mayank who has compliance stuff now and will post here. Mekki-MacAulay: Update: With the recent executive musical chairs, there is no longer a clear owner for certifications. It therefore defaults to the individual product team PMs. The guidance from Q4 2024 remains: No new watsonx certification in 2025. 2026 prioritizations will be determined after both HIPAA and FedRAMP are delivered. keely: @WATMANN Have you opened an Idea for this? FRANKO: Hi Keely, Besides opening the concrete idea I also think we need some guidance on How IBM is going to approach these required certifications ? keely: @WATMANN check out the roadmap on Seismic, certifications should be on there. I can also check it after this call. keely: @FRANKO will also follow up. @WATMANN please open an Aha Idea for this so we can add to Product Scout. FRANKO: Sharing some background info on C5 - https://www.bsi.bund.de/EN/Themen/Unternehmen-und-Organisationen/Informationen-und-Empfehlungen/Empfehlungen-nach-Angriffszielen/Cloud-Computing/Kriterienkatalog-C5/C5_Einfuehrung/C5_Einfuehrung_node.html FRANKO: FYI We have agreed to consolidate a C5 business case for DACH/Germany as C5 is firm requirement for Public/Federal customer in Germany. This is a requirement across Software and SaaS. This work will be lead by @niklas-heidloff. WATMANN: @FRANKO - excellent, thanks this is good news. Hope we can catch up quickly. niklas-heidloff: https://ibm-data-and-ai.ideas.ibm.com/ideas/WAI-I-305 FRANKO: Hi all @keely @TALS @ck-rao The DACH have done an excellent job consolidating the background and business impact on why we must secure C5 certification for our cloud and watsonx services. How can we secure this get raised with WW PM? We must have this for .ai, .gov, .assistant, .orchestrate and .data services. Public & Defense is THE growth play for DACH in 2025 and 2026. @Mayank-Arora [c5-and-IT-Grundschutz.pptx](https://github.ibm.com/customer-success-management/data-watsonx/files/1505909/c5-and-IT-Grundschutz.pptx) keely: Reviewing at Exec call next week with Ritika keely: Moving to Product Scout column keely: @niklas-heidloff Will you please add additional Impact to the idea? This was in a deck that Frank shared: ![Image](https://github.ibm.com/customer-success-management/data-watsonx/assets/1585/7dabd53a-0ade-4499-9a90-155b2d9a8abc) ck-rao: @mogle would you be able to take this one from .data and get all other players help on it, please? @Sachin-Prasad1 is this needed at the platform level? Can you look into it and help, please? Remos offered to help as well. WATMANN: As we have discussed in our call with the KKH TEL team this morning: If we could move the Inferencing workload mid-term from the dedicated self managed ROKS cluster into an On-Demand deployment that is BSI C5 certified -- would make our life much more easy from a day 2 perspective and the customer would get most out of their overall PaaS+SaaS+SW investment. In particular as we are only leveraging watsonx.ai Lightweight Engine as of today. @niklas-heidloff - whats the latest view on that? Still no new certs in 2025 / any concrete plans for certifications in 2026 ? Thanks! keely: @WATMANN Will you please add that as a comment on the Idea too? https://ideas.ibm.com/ideas/WAI-I-305 keely: Closing since this is now part of Product Scout.

Title: watsonx.ai SW text extraction API - ability to choose on-premise S3-compatible storage
Labels: enhancement, EMEA, watsonx.ai, Product: Functionality, watsonx products
Comments: ck-rao: @vijesh-bhaktha will talk to Architects and get back to @Benedikt-Bothur . vijesh-bhaktha: Discussed this with text extraction API PMs - Alex Seymour and Anthony Casaletto. We will have to wait for the architects to return from vacation. ETA - 2nd Jan. keely: Hi @vijesh-bhaktha , what is the update on this one? keely: @vijesh-bhaktha will follow up julianpayne: @Benedikt-Bothur it ought to work using a S3 compatible storage but we would need to check - @sribhaum could you have someone check this for `5.1.2` please? srikars: Tested in 5.1.1 cluster and it is working. Deployed the `MINIO` (s3 compatible storage) locally on my mac and exposed the locally hosted API endpoints to internet via ngrok. created the connection (for the datasource you can create it as ibm cloud object storage) using the minio created credentials (access_key and secret) ![image](https://github.ibm.com/customer-success-management/data-watsonx/assets/437573/7de5bc6e-6d71-471d-8f79-f8a1aee97fa9) and wdu functinality is working as expected ![image](https://github.ibm.com/customer-success-management/data-watsonx/assets/437573/9c8ee65a-8d15-441d-b51c-cec8cf6cd4d4) // @sribhaum @julianpayne Benedikt-Bothur: @srikars this looks promising. Looking forward to further test results (functional, performance, non-functional) before including it in an upcoming release. I already hear my client asking about backup and restore capabilities of this setup. keely: Hi @Benedikt-Bothur , has this issue been resolved? Benedikt-Bothur: @keely no, waiting for feedback from @srikars. Needs to be officially included into the product to have support for it. srikars: @Benedikt-Bothur any storage which supports S3 compatible api's would work ( i have tested using MINIO ... for more testing you can test with other s3 compatible storage providers ) and this is tested on CPD 5.1.1 so this is already in the product. (for 5.1.1 and further release) // @sribhaum Benedikt-Bothur: @srikars At the risk of repeating myself, this functionality must be officially documented in our product documentation. Only then, a customer can contact IBM Support if there are problems with this functionality. The current documentation includes a diagram with IBM Cloud Object Storage: https://www.ibm.com/docs/en/watsonx/w-and-w/2.1.x?topic=solutions-extract-text#conxn-id For customers who deliberately choose an on-premise installation and possibly even choose an air-gapped installation, the current implementation is simply not acceptable. @keely keely: @srikars Can we get this added to our official documentation? srikars: @julianpayne should we get this added ? julianpayne: @srikars yes please - ask the doc writer to add this for CPD - please provide an example as well for the doc writer srikars: @julianpayne @keely can you give me the contact for the doc writer ? srikars: @michellemiller could you pls add this in documentation for WDU we support on prem s3 compatible storage user has to create connection asset of type -> `ibm cloud object storage` and give the onPrem s3 compatible storage access and secret key and test the connection if the test connection is successful then they can use the connection asset for the text extraction jobs srikars: @julianpayne should we ask SVT to get this tested or this should be enough ? https://github.ibm.com/customer-success-management/data-watsonx/issues/300#issuecomment-106575449 before mentioning in the documentation julianpayne: @srikars please ask Dennis if he can add a test for this in SVT? keely: @Benedikt-Bothur has this been resolved? Benedikt-Bothur: @keely still open. keely: @julianpayne Has a test for SVT been created? julianpayne: @srikars is handling this issue srikars: we had seen some issue related to tls certificate verification https://github.ibm.com/NGP-TWC/ml-planning/issues/48680 investigating the fix for the above mentioned issue ... keely: @srikars When is this planned to be delivered? srikars: we were seeing some issues related to TLS in 5.2.0 https://github.ibm.com/NGP-TWC/ml-planning/issues/48680 we are targeting this fix for 5.2.1 // @sribhaum srikars: this has been delivered to 5.2.1 will ask the documentation team to include it once the final build is verified. keely: @srikars has the final build been verified? Vijesh said 5.2.1 will come out Aug 27th. @Benedikt-Bothur FYI srikars: The final build has been verified. We have tested it with both AWS S3 and MinIO S3, including scenarios with SSL validation enabled and disabled, as we had previously encountered issues in this area. We will open a documentation update request to clearly state that Generic S3 support is included, but has been validated only with AWS S3 and MinIO. While it is expected to work with other S3-compatible storage solutions, these have not been explicitly tested due to the variety of available providers. Generic S3 (MINIO) test details: [Test Notes](https://ibm.ent.box.com/notes/1947108877701?s=bd42yu2w9nphdu8in9na5qeu19tuducy) keely: @Benedikt-Bothur See the great update above! keely: This was delivered in 2.2.1, closing.

Title: Deployment Failure of Llama 3.3 on CPD 5.0.3 â€“ Transformer Version Issue and Potential Fix in CPD 5.1.0?
Comments: Gwangsu-Kim: @keely @TALS Who can provide an answer to this question? ck-rao: Nisarg can help per Ajay. @vijesh-bhaktha can own and help vijesh-bhaktha: Jithu Ram will own this from PM. Jithu-Ram: The development team is currently engaged in testing the model. I will update you with a confirmation as soon as the testing is finished. Gwangsu-Kim: @Jithu-Ram Thank you, can you tell me which version team are testing on? Jithu-Ram: @Gwangsu-Kim Was the software specification 'watsonx-cfm-caikit-1.1' used for the failed deployment? And what specific model was involved in the failed deployment. Gwangsu-Kim: @Jithu-Ram don't know specific 'watsonx-cfm-caikit-1.1' version. currently customer use watsonx ai v2.0.3(cpd v5.0.3) Gwangsu-Kim: @Jithu-Ram so which watsonx ai version team are testing on? Jithu-Ram: For [meta-llama/Llama-3.3-70B-Instruct](https://huggingface.co/meta-llama/Llama-3.3-70B-Instruct) model testing we need 4 GPUs. In CPD cluster we don't have 4 GPUs available currently for testing. Hence we will do the testing on cloud and confirm. For the same vLLM version, the behaviour should be the same on both. cir: @Jithu-Ram Has the testing been done? Jithu-Ram: Based on our testing we confirm that the llama-3.3-70B-Instruct model deployment will work in watsonx ai 2.1.0 (on-prem) version. @cir @Gwangsu-Kim Gwangsu-Kim: @Jithu-Ram @keely For sharing purposes, the llama 3.3 model is supported in watsonx.ai version 2.1.1 https://ibm-cloud.slack.com/archives/C05FWDB9RSA/p1738549335404349?thread_ts=1733631338.178459&cid=C05FWDB9RSA Jithu-Ram: @Gwangsu-Kim Thank you for the correction. I apologize for any inconvenience this may have caused. Gwangsu-Kim: @Jithu-Ram no problem. thanks for your support

Title: Santander Bank Executive Priority Special Exception Support for Trusted Profiles across all WatsonX Product Lines 2025
Labels: Americas, watsonx.ai, watsonx.gov, wx assistant, Product: Functionality, watsonx products
Comments: Rohana-Karina-Sosa: I created an Idea enhancement request: https://ideas.ibm.com/ideas/WGOV-I-106 CC: @cir @dilang cir: @Mekki-MacAulay @vijesh-bhaktha @Vindhya-K Can you review the above. There appears that there can be special expections made? This seems pan watsonx so looping you in Mekki Mekki-MacAulay: Looking into this. Mekki-MacAulay: Anthony Casaletto from watsonx.ai PM has confirmed that full support for Trusted Profiles in watsonx.ai is on the roadmap for 2H 2025. However, he has indicated that there will be a progressive rollout amongst watsonx.ai features--some earlier than others--and perhaps the order could be changed based on Santander's needs. What features will Santander be using in watsonx.ai? For example, another client will be primarily using Notebooks, so Trusted Profiles will be supported in Notebooks first, possibly as early as late Q1 2025. keely: @Rohana-Karina-Sosa Please see Mekki's update above, and question about which features of wx.ai Santander will be using. Rohana-Karina-Sosa: Hi @Mekki-MacAulay and @keely thank you for your timely responses and your patience, I'll reply asap as I've been handling other Santander situations in parallel. Rohana-Karina-Sosa: Hi @Mekki-MacAulay and @keely , thank you again for your timely help and for the Q1 2025 notebook support for trusted profiles. Please see below all watsonx product features the Santander client is using and deploying into production which includes the additional watsonx product lines as per our understanding from Dejan that Trusted Profiles support impacts all of the watsonx product lines; so when you can, please let me know anything you can do to speak with the product teams of the additional watsonx product lines for requesting special executive expedited roll outs of end-to-end trusted profiles support. The clientâ€™s executive Architecture Review Board (ARB) approved all of the watsonx product features implementation below for their January 22nd, 2025 target production go live date and Santanderâ€™s executive / federal audits are starting to happen from now at Santander as we speak into 2025. I look forward to your thoughts and we appreciate your continued help. Best, Rohana Sosa =================================== Yes, the Santander customer is using the Jupyter SDK notebooks for negative cases, prompt injection, etc. so please see here the IBM notebook [example](https://github.com/IBM/watson-openscale-samples/blob/main/WatsonX.Governance/Cloud/GenAI/samples/RAG%20metrics%20computation%20with%20llm%20and%20IBM%20watsonx.gov.ipynb) on git we provided the client for their implementation of LLM as Judge RAG quality evaluation metrics using watsonx.ai with watsonx.governance. The client is also using the LLM as Judge feature on the GUI. The client is using watsonx.ai and watsonx assistant LLMs where the client is leveraging watsonx.governance for implementing LLM as Judge RAG quality evaluation metrics: â€¢ Santander is using mixtral8x7b â€¢ granite built-in to watsonx assistant â€¢ granite guardian for prompt injection â€¢ what we need to evaluate is mixtral8x7b â€¢ Further, the client wants to also utilize the new llama-3.1-8B LLM watsonx.ai (wxai) â€¢ watsonx.ai API for guardrails and generation â€¢ HAP & PII Detection â€¢ Guardrail LLM â€¢ Inference LLM Responsible AI Guardrails: â€¢ watsonx.ai: Input and/or Output HAP & PII Detection (fine-tuned model) or â€¢ watsonx.ai: Input and/or Output Guardrail LLM (secondary LLM) â€¢ watsonx assistant: Intent Recognition (fine-tuned model) â€¢ "BYOR - bring your own risk" watsonx.discovery Databases for Elasticsearch (WXD) â€¢ watsonx discovery API for retrieval â€¢ Data & Vector Index â€¢ Ingest Pipeline â€¢ Embedding Model watsonx.governance (wxgov) â€¢ Context Relevance â€¢ Answer Relevance â€¢ Faithfulness â€¢ Eval LLM-as-a-Judge â€¢ KNN and chunk sizing â€¢ Define custom metrics for Recall, F1 score, precision and recall confusion matrix calculations of true / false positive and negative results when running LLMs in wxgov to be shown on the dashboard. watsonx.assistant (wxa) â€¢ watsonx assistant API for intent recognition â€¢ Intent Recognition â€¢ Analytics/ metrics to be used in custom manner for wxgov to evaluate wxa â€¢ Chatbot / Voicebot â€¢ Speech-to-Text â€¢ Text-to-Speech Mekki-MacAulay: Thanks for the details, @Rohana-Karina-Sosa. Contrary to our IBM marketing, unfortunately, watsonx isn't a single platform. It's actually a bunch of unrelated products with separate development teams and product teams wearing a trench coat, pretending to be a single platform! ^_^ Therefore, frustratingly, it's necessary to create a separate idea for each product in order for each product's product management team to review and prioritize the support of Trusted Profiles. I wish it weren't so complicated, but this is what we do at IBM, as you well know! :) Please create separate ideas requesting Trusted Profiles support in: 1. watsonx.ai (I think it's already done) 2. watsonx.governance 3. watsonx Assistant 4. watsonx Discovery 5. Cloud Pak for Data Speech to Text Cartridge (Watson Speech to Text is being replaced by this soon) 6. Cloud Pak for Data Text to Speech Cartridge (Watson Text to Speech is being replaced by this soon) 7. watsonx Orchestrate (some of watsonx Assistant will be merging into watsonx Orchestrate in 2025, so best to get ahead of it in case your client needs it) I realise this is a lot. The good news is that the Ideas portal is set up so that the ideas populate directly into the respective Aha epics/master epics of the products' product management teams so it guarantees that there is visibility and something to consistently refer to that can't be ignored! You can copy-paste the majority of the ask. Just put as many details about the features the client will use in EACH product in case--as is the case with watsonx.ai--Trusted Profile support will be added for parts of the product progressively rather than the whole product at once (The open secret being that watsonx.ai, itself, is a trenchcoat-wearing of smaller independent products! We like nested product dolls at IBM! :) ). I'll keep tracking this and help you navigate the fun as things move forward. Rohana-Karina-Sosa: Hi @Mekki-MacAulay, thanks very much for your detailed response! Totally understand! ^_^ I'll work on this as soon as possible as I was continuing to handle other Santander matters this week. I appreciate your patience and all your supportive collaboration with me. Best, Rohana Sosa oscarcordon: For watsonx.ai, the client (Santander) is using at this moment only prompting and inferencing. They are not using machine learning models either fine tunning. You are receiving this because you were mentioned.Message ID: ***@***.***> Rohana-Karina-Sosa: Updates: The client, Bernd, announced during todayâ€™s Santander executive daily call that CISO Rebbeca is okay with leveraging IBM Verify Multi-Factor Auth (MFA) that sends one time passwords via email (as per the [IBM Docs](https://cloud.ibm.com/docs/account?topic=account-verification-authentication)) that Bernd showed us they tested in combination with watsonx local user accounts to login; therefore, this is Santanderâ€™s decision to move forward as a temporary workaround for deploying to production on 01/27 while the IBM Teams work on the watsonx trusted profiles early release for 1H 2025. Next Internal Meeting is this Friday, Jan. 17th from 8:00 â€“ 8:30am EST. Agenda: the purpose of this wxai / wxgov internal team call with Ravi is to discuss sizing the work for 1H 2025 and requesting the wxgov Development Executive to agree on a trusted profiles early feature release commitment with wxai teams: Dejan, Vijesh, wxai Development Executive and Anthony. Rohana-Karina-Sosa: Fri. Jan. 17th 2025 8:00am EST Internal Santander call about support for trusted profiles with wxgov and wxai executive product and development teams. IBM Internal meeting notes / next steps below and updated [git ticket here](https://github.ibm.com/customer-success-management/watsonx/issues/297): â€¢ The Santander client uses Entra ID azure active directory; the client is making API calls to wxai and using the wxgov GUI for LLM as a Judge. â€¢ Dejanâ€™s helpful explanations: o What makes the trusted profiles implementation unique is that Santander has an Enterprise IBM Cloud account with many embedded child accounts. Trusted profiles is a complex concept specific to only IBM Cloud where trusted profiles does not exist on prem. With trusted profiles, the identity is transient and only lightly cached for audits; what you do to and how you treat identities is unique. o e.g. Citibank was the first customer who wanted trusted profiles for SAML assertions on IBM Cloud and there are more clients / growing trends of financial institutions / banks who want trusted profiles. o There are three main categories of problems exist: ï‚§ 1) when a user logs in via trusted profiles, the GUI does not render correctly, the tokens are different and we need to support the unique access token. ï‚§ 2) wxgov environment characteristics including projects, spaces, catalogs, etc. need to handle membership for trusted profiles; e.g. the trusted profile admin will be determined if they are a member or not; if they are a member, then we need to assign role access. ï‚§ 3) There are issues in how to access API keys programmatically in wxgov. ï‚§ Overall, trusted profiles cannot handle tokens or tools because it cannot handle the membership; 100% of all the services / tools need to first support trusted profiles where itâ€™s required to make changes everywhere across the board in a phased delivery approach. o Neil and Ravi: ï‚§ wxgov product and development teams will evaluate Santanderâ€™s requirements we shared to start creating a phased roll out delivery plan on how to implement the trusted profiles features with wxai / IBM Cloud teams incrementally by 2025; Rohana and Oscar raised awareness during this call about Santanderâ€™s internal InfoSec CISO waiver about the enterprise wide requirement for trusted profiles across Santander globally to be able deploy watsonx at scale across the Santander enterprise. Neil said slack and email is okay to keep in touch while the product dev teams start working on this and will let us know any questions. Rohana-Karina-Sosa: Hi Team, re: adding wxgov trusted profiles support on the product roadmap: it'd be very helpful to please let us know any thoughts on how we can help re-prioritize this situation anytime when you have a second today 02/21 or by Monday 02/24. Today, 02/21, I saw Sayakaâ€™s comments on the other [git ticket](https://github.ibm.com/aiopenscale/tracker/issues/41092) from two weeks ago saying the following: â€œ[@TMKAZ](https://github.ibm.com/TMKAZ) [@Akinobu-Morishima](https://github.ibm.com/Akinobu-Morishima) let me remove your assignments and move this to Backlog as Madhavi requested Siddhi to push it back for now, as we are already seeing multiple issues and don't have much time to provide the estimate.â€ Unfortunately, this statement of â€œpushing it backâ€ is concerning to us all and itâ€™d be very helpful that we please have an open internal conversation on how we can help re-prioritize this situation please. We have another meeting confirmed with Eduardo M Gonzalez, Senior Director, Information Security at Santander Bank, N.A., (LinkedIn Sales Nav link [here](https://www.linkedin.com/sales/lead/ACwAAACQTX0BFZ6FEHT5S1ma1LFPVNRL2eOzKKw,NAME_SEARCH,miEz)), this Monday 02/24 at 10am EST where again it would be very helpful to please tell us any wxgov roadmap update to be prepared to respond to Eduardo on where we are with adding wxgov trusted profiles support on the roadmap. Again, we are kindly raising awareness about the clients to help everyone here please understand Eduardo's intense personality as again we are trying to mitigate any potential unexpected risks of the watsonx deployments. Please understand we've worked very hard to retain watsonx at Santander who all love watsonx and are growing very well with us at IBM so it would be incredibly unfortunate if down the road in the near future (e.g. Q2 2025) someone like Eduardo then changes his mind about watsonx governance adoption since Eduardo is a major highly significant Sr. Executive decision maker at Santander. Title: Adani Issues, product fixes and and response to the customer
Comments: ck-rao: An note from Krian, Director CS, from ISA/India: The Observations & Best practices compiled by Nitika has also shared with ISA PreSales, Sales leadership , IBMC & Support teams- for necessary improvements that can be brought in proactively Looking forward to your response - post your take of the Product & Operational Issues with the PM teams ck-rao: Watsonx.data issues for Adani: Unexpected response from data inserted to the table There was some catalog issue on one of the worker. Basically, catalogs on one of worker pod were missing. We recreated the respective worker pod to fix this issue. Reference Case - CS4041299. Presto environment not accessible - The issue was be due to the formation updates progressing in the us-south region. Once upgrade was completed, engines were accessible. Reference Case - CS4082678, Reference GIT â€“ [16180](https://github.ibm.com/lakehouse/tracker/issues/16180) Table locked - Waiting for lock - Dev recommendation : HMS will be replaced with MDS in release 2.1. Revalidate the issue once MDS is live and take it from there. Since MDS has a different architecture all together compared to HMS(based on OSS framework), it may get resolved. Reference Case - CS4098046, Reference GIT â€“ [16522](https://github.ibm.com/lakehouse/tracker/issues/16522) Unavailability of Presto engine in the environment and Query slowness and intermittent 520 error from wxd console -We identified the problematic node on which lhconsole-api pod was restarting and cordoned that node. Post which issue is fixed. Discussing on the possible fix. Reference Case - CS4127675, Reference GIT â€“ [17552](https://github.ibm.com/lakehouse/tracker/issues/17552) and [17421](https://github.ibm.com/lakehouse/tracker/issues/17421) IAE : Jobs failing due to spark cluster getting disconnected - Same as CS4120278. For given application, we have observed the issue to be cluster capacity at the given time. But we have also identified some optimization for better scheduling and deployed the fix in Dallas production. Reference Case - CS4174482 Unable to access views from Spark â€“ Interoperability issue The views created in Spark cannot be queried on by Presto, and the ones created in Presto cannot be queried on, in Spark. This is mainly because of the difference in SQL dialect in the two engines. Reference Case - CS4162153 , Reference GIT â€“ [19035](https://github.ibm.com/lakehouse/tracker/issues/19035) SQL Merge INTO & Spark UDF compatibility issue This seems to be a bug in Iceberg where the continuous computation cannot be handled by it. So, the tempView needs a caching before it. Reference Case - CS4071852, Reference GIT - [15661](https://github.ibm.com/lakehouse/tracker/issues/15661) ck-rao: Summary of the points we need to come up with an explanation, best practice or an action item fix in the product: 1. Catalogs on one of the worker pods were missing. 2. Presto: The environment is not accessible while formation updates progressing in the us-south region. 3. Table locks: HMS will be replaced with MDS in release 2.1. 4. Presto: problematic node on which lhconsole-api pod was restarting and cordoned that node 5. Spark Cluster capacity issues at certain times. optimization for better scheduling best practices. 6. The views created in Spark cannot be queried on by Presto, and vice versa due to difference in SQL dialect in the two engines. 7. SQL Merge into Spark UDF: Bug in Iceberg where the continuous computation cannot be handled by it. So a tempView needs caching. ck-rao: All the issues are addressed as of today. We will keep an eye on this high-profile customer every week to bring visibility. vijesh-bhaktha: @ck-rao - Specific to watsonx.ai issue. The rate limit was increased to 25 from 8 as requested. https://github.ibm.com/NGP-TWC/watsonx-ai-onboarding/issues/313#issuecomment-98294216 keely: Closing issue, CK confirmed fixes have been delivered. Will open a new issue if needed.

Knowing this together with associated revenue and any context on why the lack of graph database blocks an acceptable solution for these clients daniel-lsainz: Anthony, thank you for your inquiry about the rationale behind the graph database proposal. While thereâ€™s no immediate client request, this initiative aligns with a strategic analysis of AI development platformsâ€™ competitive differentiation. Allow me to share my framework: Three Pillars of Modern AI Development Environments 1 AI-Augmented Code Development: Capabilities for code generation, optimization, and maintenance via native AI collaboration. 2 Collaboration Infrastructure: Team workflow integration, MLOps compatibility, and UX/UI sophistication. 3 Toolchain Sophistication: Native support for emerging architectures (e.g., advanced RAG, multi-agent systems) and enterprise-grade data paradigms. Current watsonx.ai Positioning â€¢ Pillar 1: Not yet addressed (I also opened a RFE for this one) â€¢ Pillar 2: Competent baseline â€¢ Pillar 3: High-impact opportunity area! Why Graph Databases Are Critical Integrating graph technology would: 1 Improve RAG Accuracy: Enable semantic relationships between entities (users  queries  data), reducing hallucination risks 2 Future-Proof Architecture: Support emerging use cases like knowledge graph-powered agents and multi-hop reasoning pipelines. 3 Market Leadership: Differentiate us from competitors relying on vector-only RAG implementations (e.g., AWS Bedrock, Azure AI Studio, DataIKU, Codeium). Strategic Context While Iâ€™m aware of your current workloads, this represents a tier-1 opportunity to lead rather than follow in enterprise AI

Title: Clarification Needed on GPU Requirements and Memory Specifications for Llama 3.1 70B Instruct
Comments: michelle-miller: The documentation states that 8 GPUs are required for Llama 3.1 70B in the 5.0.3 release because the service is configured to expect 8 GPUs. If the customer wants to use fewer, they need to take steps to use fewer. There is a documented workaround that customers must follow to change the configuration. If the installation process allowed users to choose whether to use 4 or 8 GPUs at installation time, we would document that both are supported and that you can choose one or the other configuration. Is the request that we remove the documented workaround so that we don't confuse customers? The Foundation models topic states which GPUs are supported.  Note that A100 40GB is not listed. As noted, the table of models specifies any models that cannot run on L40S GPUs. For example:  Gwangsu-Kim: @michelle-miller thanks for reply. yes, we think it would be clearer to document that both configurations are supported and that customers can choose the configuration they prefer. In that case, the workaround you mentioned would no longer be necessary.

Comments: FRANKO: @keely @TALS @vijesh-bhaktha - Who can help respond to these request from BaFin? cir: @mehboob and @vijesh-bhaktha How can we address this? and who do we need to work on this? mehboob: This is a RH question/topic. For IBM images, we publish everything on [icr.io](http://icr.io/). RH images are published in multiple registry, some of the registry like [quay.io](http://quay.io/) are not necessarily adhering to any security/compliance standard. But RH can comment on it. vijesh-bhaktha: I have reached out to RH team for response. cir: @ncolon Is this something you can assist with? vijesh-bhaktha: Myriam Fentanes and Jeff DeMoss are the contacts on RH side. They have passed the questions to their Engineering team for answers. ck-rao: Per Nikoals, team is working on it, and changed the to assigned. vijesh-bhaktha: Expecting delay as per Myriam Fentanes - The RH engineering team advised to route the questions to RH prodsec team. This involves a process where their legal department also has to approve the information they can share. Awaiting details. vijesh-bhaktha: **Question 1 Reply** Red Hat regularly conducts vulnerability assessments on Red Hat OpenShift AI releases, including scans during both development and post-release stages. The answers to any secure software lifecycle (SDLC), software security testing, code reviews, Vulnerability Management, Incident Response, etc..are described in Product Security's Security Declaration on Secure Software Development Life Cycle. [[https://access.redhat.com/security/rh_security_declaration_sdl](https://urldefense.proofpoint.com/v2/url?u=https-3A__access.redhat.com_security_rh-5Fsecurity-5Fdeclaration-5Fsdl&d=DwMFaQ&c=BSDicqBQBDjDI9RkVyTcHQ&r=DkaZf3xhFHIdbPGhwJOp9RxiaA9zDzSd1fk2WmDdgMM&m=pmW3ajOai5QtI3X_zEajyenanNE0tRIs2yxXWHqVr50W-wW6H3cM3EePX-ChHOg3&s=rxQ2ftGBFmzpEDWFkcaIZ6kA0pIEC-AxVb_0oLzuZlA&e=)] This declaration is publicly accessible and can be shared with all customers. If a customer cannot access that page, a .pdf version can be downloaded and provided to them. (this slide deck can be shared by downloading a copy) Red Hat Product Security Vulnerability Management & Incident Response Plan (VIRP) ([https://access.redhat.com/articles/2968471](https://urldefense.proofpoint.com/v2/url?u=https-3A__access.redhat.com_articles_2968471&d=DwMFaQ&c=BSDicqBQBDjDI9RkVyTcHQ&r=DkaZf3xhFHIdbPGhwJOp9RxiaA9zDzSd1fk2WmDdgMM&m=pmW3ajOai5QtI3X_zEajyenanNE0tRIs2yxXWHqVr50W-wW6H3cM3EePX-ChHOg3&s=peWZgV0f__3n-1vhAIsAcPCXBlNW93VxX9CDTx3YIXg&e=)): This plan alerts key internal stakeholders and assists in directing the required resources to be allocated for the correction, testing, and distribution of the fixes to our subscribers to resolve the vulnerability. CVE, short for Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures, is a list of publicly disclosed computer security flaws. CVE is also shorthand for the CVE ID number assigned to a security flaw. CVEs help IT professionals coordinate their efforts to prioritize and address these vulnerabilities to make computer networks more secure. Red Hat Product Security strives to provide the most actionable information about vulnerabilities, so specialized Security Bulletins ([https://access.redhat.com/security/vulnerabilities](https://urldefense.proofpoint.com/v2/url?u=https-3A__access.redhat.com_security_vulnerabilities&d=DwMFaQ&c=BSDicqBQBDjDI9RkVyTcHQ&r=DkaZf3xhFHIdbPGhwJOp9RxiaA9zDzSd1fk2WmDdgMM&m=pmW3ajOai5QtI3X_zEajyenanNE0tRIs2yxXWHqVr50W-wW6H3cM3EePX-ChHOg3&s=xo0RihRrqNIrxGSRBRgCjdDmCcaeginq-9ux3VSAWtU&e=)) are created to offer the best experience and information possible. These security bulletins aggregate information, diagnostic tools, and updates in one easy-to-understand interface. In addition, when new product releases are made available that have security fixes included, these Security Bulletins will highlight those fixes to assist in decisions about upgrading to newer versions. A full list of all CVEs affecting Red Hat Products can be found in our CVE Database ([https://access.redhat.com/security/security-updates/cve](https://urldefense.proofpoint.com/v2/url?u=https-3A__access.redhat.com_security_security-2Dupdates_cve&d=DwMFaQ&c=BSDicqBQBDjDI9RkVyTcHQ&r=DkaZf3xhFHIdbPGhwJOp9RxiaA9zDzSd1fk2WmDdgMM&m=pmW3ajOai5QtI3X_zEajyenanNE0tRIs2yxXWHqVr50W-wW6H3cM3EePX-ChHOg3&s=XAUAtp5Q7yUl9g4rHr4NLaBGCFJ3Le_QJOYHoeYMgp4&e=)). How Red Hat works with CVEs: As a major contributor to open source software, Red Hat continuously engages in the security community. Red Hat is a Root CVE Numbering Authority (Root CNA [https://www.cve.org/Media/News/item/blog/2022/09/07/CVE-Program-Expands-Partnership-with](https://urldefense.proofpoint.com/v2/url?u=https-3A__www.cve.org_Media_News_item_blog_2022_09_07_CVE-2DProgram-2DExpands-2DPartnership-2Dwith&d=DwMFaQ&c=BSDicqBQBDjDI9RkVyTcHQ&r=DkaZf3xhFHIdbPGhwJOp9RxiaA9zDzSd1fk2WmDdgMM&m=pmW3ajOai5QtI3X_zEajyenanNE0tRIs2yxXWHqVr50W-wW6H3cM3EePX-ChHOg3&s=9V53nBA-FvQ6xDY6qK7N_LS46gTC1wmbVt_iajM96H0&e=)) and uses CVE IDs to track security vulnerabilities. Red Hat Security maintains an open and frequently updated database of security updates (CVE database), which you can view by CVE number. All vulnerabilities are reported as discovered / triaged and posted within our CVE database. [https://access.redhat.com/security/](https://urldefense.proofpoint.com/v2/url?u=https-3A__access.redhat.com_security_&d=DwMFaQ&c=BSDicqBQBDjDI9RkVyTcHQ&r=DkaZf3xhFHIdbPGhwJOp9RxiaA9zDzSd1fk2WmDdgMM&m=pmW3ajOai5QtI3X_zEajyenanNE0tRIs2yxXWHqVr50W-wW6H3cM3EePX-ChHOg3&s=nHKBnGBvfVgaRUoqldQBlvAxQi0dA-qSen7--l9-AdE&e=) for customer guidance on security incidents. All currently supported product releases, versions, and patches can be retrieved from the Red Hat Customer Portal. Customers can subscribe to advisories and notifications to receive information about releases and patches. Note that Red Hat has a specific Red Hat Product Security Incident Response Team that will, among other things, define the Severity level of CVEs, on top of the traditional CVSS score. See [https://access.redhat.com/security/overview/](https://urldefense.proofpoint.com/v2/url?u=https-3A__access.redhat.com_security_overview_&d=DwMFaQ&c=BSDicqBQBDjDI9RkVyTcHQ&r=DkaZf3xhFHIdbPGhwJOp9RxiaA9zDzSd1fk2WmDdgMM&m=pmW3ajOai5QtI3X_zEajyenanNE0tRIs2yxXWHqVr50W-wW6H3cM3EePX-ChHOg3&s=c-bjT_N2TK-4mckn38oG7x4CivCVHkZJzbybkec4wKo&e=) and [https://access.redhat.com/security/updates/classification/](https://urldefense.proofpoint.com/v2/url?u=https-3A__access.redhat.com_security_updates_classification_&d=DwMFaQ&c=BSDicqBQBDjDI9RkVyTcHQ&r=DkaZf3xhFHIdbPGhwJOp9RxiaA9zDzSd1fk2WmDdgMM&m=pmW3ajOai5QtI3X_zEajyenanNE0tRIs2yxXWHqVr50W-wW6H3cM3EePX-ChHOg3&s=R8OYw4cyNXwNeBypMxAx1ZdOKzsdJtN1wY88KGxDcg8&e=) Red Hat issues an annual Product Security Risk Report on our public customer portal. Customers can review findings and vulnerabilities and how we plan to address those within our products. Please the latest risk report at [https://access.redhat.com/security/vulnerability-management](https://urldefense.proofpoint.com/v2/url?u=https-3A__access.redhat.com_security_vulnerability-2Dmanagement&d=DwMFaQ&c=BSDicqBQBDjDI9RkVyTcHQ&r=DkaZf3xhFHIdbPGhwJOp9RxiaA9zDzSd1fk2WmDdgMM&m=pmW3ajOai5QtI3X_zEajyenanNE0tRIs2yxXWHqVr50W-wW6H3cM3EePX-ChHOg3&s=t_3c31VVAFJ2E8Ar1ZjeeJWq04DuRK85iNj566rM4x4&e=) All issues are resolved according to SLAs and are publicly available and document in the product release notes [https://docs.redhat.com/en/documentation/red_hat_openshift_ai/2024](https://urldefense.proofpoint.com/v2/url?u=https-3A__docs.redhat.com_en_documentation_red-5Fhat-5Fopenshift-5Fai_2024&d=DwMFaQ&c=BSDicqBQBDjDI9RkVyTcHQ&r=DkaZf3xhFHIdbPGhwJOp9RxiaA9zDzSd1fk2WmDdgMM&m=pmW3ajOai5QtI3X_zEajyenanNE0tRIs2yxXWHqVr50W-wW6H3cM3EePX-ChHOg3&s=I6xJPT8sNYRLnO_mgfjzmRt5kp96KutDwAQYxjoCLvU&e=) **Question 3 Reply** [Quay.io](https://urldefense.proofpoint.com/v2/url?u=http-3A__quay.io_&d=DwMFaQ&c=BSDicqBQBDjDI9RkVyTcHQ&r=DkaZf3xhFHIdbPGhwJOp9RxiaA9zDzSd1fk2WmDdgMM&m=pmW3ajOai5QtI3X_zEajyenanNE0tRIs2yxXWHqVr50W-wW6H3cM3EePX-ChHOg3&s=0YCL7Pe2mTM2lHOXBKTfYLXs0BRvOuAuU8Ob1TtLIyM&e=) is a Red Hat supported product [https://docs.redhat.com/en/documentation/red_hat_quay/3.13#Quay.io](https://urldefense.proofpoint.com/v2/url?u=https-3A__docs.redhat.com_en_documentation_red-5Fhat-5Fquay_3.13-23Quay.io&d=DwMFaQ&c=BSDicqBQBDjDI9RkVyTcHQ&r=DkaZf3xhFHIdbPGhwJOp9RxiaA9zDzSd1fk2WmDdgMM&m=pmW3ajOai5QtI3X_zEajyenanNE0tRIs2yxXWHqVr50W-wW6H3cM3EePX-ChHOg3&s=OliT9OXGQ62c5QlUNtgAJSHVai2-jG2yBdV0PgWqRxQ&e=) and Red Hat regularly conducts vulnerability assessments on Red Hat [Quay.io](https://urldefense.proofpoint.com/v2/url?u=http-3A__quay.io_&d=DwMFaQ&c=BSDicqBQBDjDI9RkVyTcHQ&r=DkaZf3xhFHIdbPGhwJOp9RxiaA9zDzSd1fk2WmDdgMM&m=pmW3ajOai5QtI3X_zEajyenanNE0tRIs2yxXWHqVr50W-wW6H3cM3EePX-ChHOg3&s=0YCL7Pe2mTM2lHOXBKTfYLXs0BRvOuAuU8Ob1TtLIyM&e=) releases, including scans during both development and post-release stages. The answers to any secure software lifecycle (SDLC), software security testing, code reviews, Vulnerability Management, Incident Response, etc..are described in Product Security's Security Declaration on Secure Software Development Life Cycle. [[https://access.redhat.com/security/rh_security_declaration_sdl](https://urldefense.proofpoint.com/v2/url?u=https-3A__access.redhat.com_security_rh-5Fsecurity-5Fdeclaration-5Fsdl&d=DwMFaQ&c=BSDicqBQBDjDI9RkVyTcHQ&r=DkaZf3xhFHIdbPGhwJOp9RxiaA9zDzSd1fk2WmDdgMM&m=pmW3ajOai5QtI3X_zEajyenanNE0tRIs2yxXWHqVr50W-wW6H3cM3EePX-ChHOg3&s=rxQ2ftGBFmzpEDWFkcaIZ6kA0pIEC-AxVb_0oLzuZlA&e=)] This declaration is publicly accessible and can be shared with all customers. If a customer cannot access that page, a .pdf version can be downloaded and provided to them. elke-kunde: Thanks for the answers to the Red Hat part. Any idea for question #2 specific list of artefacts required by watsonx ? vijesh-bhaktha: @elke-kunde - for Qn 2 quay.io should be enough. But I need to get it confirmed with the team.
